You probably know this. This idea, an arc in a vacuum, is used everyday in the steel industry.
VAR (vacuum arc remelting) remelts the metal under a vacuum to further refining air melted steels, removing inclusions.
VIM (vacuum induction melting) this is the coolest! acutally melting and refining under vacuum and pouring it into molds.
another non-vacuum process is ESR (electro-slag remelting)

Most of the steels in planes and other critical application are produced using one or more of these method. VIM-VAR is popular.

The problem is that an arc doesn't carry in a vacuum. The whole idea of an electric arc is the higher the voltage the more easily it is for electrons to jump from one atom to another and the further away those atoms can be. Eventually, it becomes high enough for the electrons to jump about the various atoms in the air which are usually too far apart for electricity to flow through. If you pull all the air out, as in a vacuum, there are no (or few) atoms for the electrons to form a path across and so they would have to bridge the gap in a single jump purely from one atom of one carbon rod to an atom from the other. While theoretically possible, it would take an absurd amount of voltage to achieve.

What is interesting to me is the potential of melting things in a vacuum or a non-oxygenated atmosphere (replacing the air with nitrogen or an inert gas). Without oxygen, metals wouldn't oxidize when heated and would cause them to behave differently than standard furnaces, which is one major benefit of an arc furnace (normal furnaces require oxygen to function and produce CO2 anyway).

One thing to be careful of is the fact that without air at all, the carbon rods will heat up quite quickly and take a lot longer to cool down. Removing air forces the heat to dissipate purely through radiation instead of conduction through the air or a replacement gas. Though graphite is one of the better materials at radiating heat in a vacuum, it's still significantly less than what it can do in atmosphere.

Two interesting comments. 1) This is the way carbon nanoparticles were first discovered. Carbon rods were arced like this and the fine, smoke-like products were collected and then analyzed. Molecules of C1, C2, C3, etc were found in small amounts, but the chromatograph peaked at carbon-60 (C60). Buckyballs were discovered, then other fullerenes like carbon nanotubes.
2) Also, the fog observed when first switching on the vacuum pump was due to thermal cooling associated with pulling a vacuum (gas expansion). The paths of subatomic particles were first observed, using the same method. As alpha particles, cosmic rays, beta particles, etc move through the fog, they cause a thin trail of condensation in their wake. CERN and Fermilab both used similar fog chambers during their early days.

The problem is that the electricity needs something to travel by. In air the air molecules themselves ionize and provide a path. In vacuum, that option is gone and the distance us reduced

Of course you can't make an arc in vacuum, you need some kind of gas to excite in order to make plasma, which is what you need to make a lightning/arc.

Plasma is like a fourth state of matter from solid -> liquid -> gas -> plasma, so you need gas in order to make plasma, which you need to make an arc.

So if you have a pressure chamber and increase the the amount of gas you should be able to extend the arc.
The Amount of energy needed to excite a gas is different from gas to gas, so some gas is easier to excite then others.
The first light bulb was a trial and error of finding the correct pressure, gas and material to excite the gas.
